body:
Thx for noting it down. We might consider switching to that. I see that it is also available to ```apt```. But I don't know if phonemizer supports it as an alternative backend. 

Do you have any idea, what are the differences or improvements in general over ```espeak```? 

It is better if you could send a PR covering the related [tests](https://github.com/mozilla/TTS/blob/master/tests/test_text_processing.py) and the updates. I can also train and test if it makes any difference, better or worse.
@twerkmeister maybe you could try ```speak-ng``` for german if it solves the problems you told.

I'll take a deeper look into espeak-ng and at the tests as you suggested (I have should some time on Monday)

Just to confirm: Phonemiser definitely supports both, specifically mentioning this near the top of the [README](https://github.com/bootphon/phonemizer/blob/master/README.md):

> espeak-ng is a text-to-speech software supporting multiple languages and IPA (Internatinal Phonetic Alphabet) output. See https://github.com/espeak-ng/espeak-ng. Alternatively you can use the orginal espeak program (espeak-ng is a fork of espeak supporting much more languages and significant improvements).

I haven't (_yet_) done a complete training test with it, my tests were only when doing inference on a previously trained model (trained with espeak) so I agree it makes sense to check that for impact.

unfortunately, espeak-ng does not solve the problem with german umlauts. On top of that I had some question marks in the output. Only saw the question mark with 1 out of 4 test sentences, but still a bit odd. It also happens when using the phonemizer from the command line, so outside of our code.

Sentence: Angela Merkel ist als Klimakanzlerin gestartet. Dann vernachlässigte sie das Thema. Nun, kurz vor dem Ende, will sie damit noch einmal neu anfangen.

phonemizer with Espeak-ng:
anɡəlɑː mɛɾkəl ɪst als kliːmakantslərɪn ɡəʃtaɾtət. dan fɛɾnaxlasɪçtə ziː das teːmɑː. nuːn, **k??ts** fɔɾ deːm ɛndə, vɪl ziː dɑːmɪt nɔx aɪnmɑːl nɔø anfaŋən.

phonemizer with espeak:
anɡəlɑː mɛɾkəl ɪst als kliːmakantslərɪn ɡəʃtaɾtət. dan fɛɾnaxlasɪçtə ziː das teːmɑː. nuːn, **kʊɐts** fɔɾ deːm ɛndə, vɪl ziː dɑːmɪt nɔx aɪnmɑːl nɔø anfaŋən.

both get fɛɾnaxlasɪçtə wrong which should be fɛɾnaxlɛsɪçtə

Wonder if this is an encoding issue, just tried from the python repl:

```
phonemize("Schöne Grüße aus Österreich", strip=False, njobs=1, backend='espeak', language="de")
'ʃøːnə ɡryːsə aʊs œstɜraɪç '

```
Also, your sentence @twerkmeister 
```
phonemize("Angela Merkel ist als Klimakanzlerin gestartet. Dann vernachlässigte sie das Thema. Nun, kurz vor dem Ende, will sie damit noch einmal neu anfangen.", strip=False, njobs=1, backend='espeak', language="de")
'anɡəlɑː mɛɾkəl ɪst als kliːmakantslərɪn ɡəʃtaɾtət \ndan fɛɾnaxlɛsɪçtə ziː das teːmɑː \nnuːn \nkʊɐts fɔɾ deːm ɛndə \nvɪl ziː dɑːmɪt nɔx  aɪnmɑːl nɔø anfaŋən '

```

Then installed espeak-ng (phonemizer is a bit unclear here, it searches for espeak-ng and uses the classic espeak as fallback, yet the is_espeak_ng function does not work correctly at the moment)

```
phonemizer.backend.EspeakBackend.espeak_exe()
'/usr/bin/espeak-ng'

phonemize("Angela Merkel ist als Klimakanzlerin gestartet. Dann vernachlässigte sie das Thema. Nun, kurz vor dem Ende, will sie damit noch einmal neu anfangen.", strip=False, njobs=1, backend='espeak', language="de")
'anɡəlɑː mɛɾkəl ɪst als kliːmakantslərɪn ɡəʃtaɾtət \ndan fɛɾnaxlɛsɪçtə ziː das teːmɑː \nnuːn \nkʊɐts fɔɾ deːm ɛndə \nvɪl ziː dɑːmɪt nɔx aɪnmɑːl nɔø anfaŋən '
```
hmm could be! Also, interesting that you get the proper **ɛ** in `fɛɾnaxlɛsɪçtə` (vernachlässigte) with both solutions, and I didn't get it with either
maybe my installation of espeak and espeak-ng on macos is outdated or messed up in some way. Will double check inside a ubuntu docker container
on my ubuntu server I am also getting the proper result, just tested with espeak so far

What's interesting is that the espeak under ubuntu removes all punctuation. This is a bit of a pity as it would certainly be important information for pauses in the speech or for intonation (questions vs statements).
Here's what I learned about this issue so far: 
1. Unfortunately, right now there is no command line option for espeak to keep the punctuation as in the source text (https://github.com/espeak-ng/espeak-ng/issues/275)
2. There is a command line option `--punct` that leads to punctuation being pronounced explicitly, i.e `, -> comma`. It would certainly be possible to use this and then have a use a regex on the resulting pattern. Possibly enclosing punctuation in other rare symbols to make the result more unique, e.g. `@,@`.
3. Apart from that I saw that the phonemizer module removes stress marks from the resulting phoneme sequence. I wonder wether this is desirable or if we should actually keep those.

I also looked at this just now. 
There is this workaround:
https://github.com/mozilla/TTS/blob/b1657d70b160c097be7ac24290514a9aed010452/utils/text/__init__.py#L33

I wonder if it would be beneficial to not have diacritics etc as separate symbols. Also diphones are split at the moment.
Ah great, so this is already being taken care of. That explains why I saw the punctuation in the notebooks before! Thanks for double checking :+1:

Is there a preference towards supporting just one version (ie original espeak or espeak-ng) or both?

It shouldn't be _that_ hard to handle both, just the tests would need to be able to take it into account (they differ in their phoneme output) and it does provide one more thing to confuse people (but the counter point is that one or other may be easier to install depending on the environment people are using, thus being more helpful to end users)

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions. You might also look our discourse page for further help. https://discourse.mozilla.org/c/tts
